sn52.2:1.2: Then as Anuruddha was in private retreat this thought came to his mind:
sn52.2:1.3: “Whoever has missed out on these four kinds of mindfulness meditation has missed out on the noble path to the complete ending of suffering.
sn52.2:1.4: Whoever has undertaken these four kinds of mindfulness meditation has undertaken the noble path to the complete ending of suffering.”
sn52.2:2.1: Then Venerable Mahāmoggallāna knew what Venerable Anuruddha was thinking. As easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, he reappeared in front of Anuruddha and said to him:
sn52.2:3.1: “Reverend Anuruddha, how do you define the undertaking of the four kinds of mindfulness meditation by a mendicant?”
sn52.2:4.1: “Reverend, it’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body internally—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn52.2:4.2: They meditate observing an aspect of the body externally …
sn52.2:4.3: internally and externally—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn52.2:5.1: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings internally …
sn52.2:6.1: They meditate observing an aspect of the mind internally …
sn52.2:7.1: They meditate observing an aspect of principles internally …
sn52.2:7.3: internally and externally—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn52.2:7.4: That’s how to define the undertaking of the four kinds of mindfulness meditation by a mendicant.”
